Graphical abstract The present critical review outlines the close relationship and mutual interplay between molecular recognition, active site considerations in enzyme catalysis involving organocatalysis via hydrogen bonding. These interconnections are generally not made although; as we demonstrated they are quite apparent as exemplified with pertinent examples in the field of urea organocatalysis. Urea organocatalysis derivatives have been used as efficient Lewis-acidic catalysts due to effective H-bonding, basic catalyst, coupling with metals as catalyst, chiral acid catalysts, urea anions catalysts, coupling with ionic liquids, urea polymer catalysts and immobilization on solid acid and magnetic nanoparticle supports. Consecutively, the discovery and mechanistic elucidation of such reactions are likely to improve the understanding of enzyme active sites. Keywords Urea Catalyst Hydrogen-bonding catalyst Chiral urea Enantioselective reactions 1 Introduction Diazo compounds participate in a variety of attractive bond-forming reactions [1]. Conventionally, the useful reactivity patterns of diazo compounds are often accessed with the aid of transition metal catalysis [2]. Recent advances in hydrogen-bond-donor catalysis [3–16] have demonstrated the potential to develop new and useful reactivity patterns that are difficult and/or inaccessible with transition metal catalysis [17]. Urea and its derivatives are examples of biological diazo compounds. Substituted ureas have found widespread use as agricultural chemicals, pharmaceuticals, resin precursors, dyes, and additives to petroleum compounds and polymers [18]. One of the uses of urea and its derivatives is their use as a fertilizer and growth regulator. Fertilizers play a vital role to guarantee enough crops to meet the increasing population food needs and the progressive energy requirements. Among the nutrients required by plants, nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium are essential and, therefore, used in large quantities. Urea is the most important nitrogenous source consumed by the agriculture sector both as a fertilizer and animal feed additive, which makes its production considerably higher than others. It has the highest nitrogen content (46 wt%) within all the other solid sources of nitrogen available in the market [19–22]. Forchlorfenuron, formaly1-(2-chloropyridin-4-yl)-3-phenyl urea (CPPU) with a urea moiety, is a growth regulator too that increases the size (and therefore the value) of such fruits as apple, cherry, and kiwi. It has been used on watermelon too; but at least once, the results were unexpected. In China in 2011, about 20 farmers applied too much CPPU on their watermelon crops too late in the growing season. The weather conditions were ideal, so much so that the watermelons grew too fast and exploded. The watermelon fragments, about 46 ha worth, were used to feed fish and pigs [23,24]. Urea has been used for synthesis of energetic materials with various forms such as urea nitrate, [25,26] nitrourea [27–32] and dinitrourea [33–40]. Also urea derivatives have been applied as reagent in various organic transformations [26,41–46]. Among the numerous methods for synthesis of N,N-disubstituted ureas are the reactions of primary amines with isocyanates, phosgene, or phosgene derivatives [47]. While reports describing the synthesis of disubstituted ureas are prevalent, methods for the synthesis of tetrasubstituted ureas are less common, due to the difficulty of converting secondary amines directly to tetrasubstituted ureas [48]. Urea is a widely used protein denaturant. Despite its widespread use, however, the molecular mechanism underlying urea-induced denaturation is not well understood. Two classes of interaction models are distinguished in the literature. In the first, direct interactions between urea and the protein are considered the main denaturation driving force [49–53]. In the second, urea-induced changes in the water structure are suggested as indirect interactions that drive unfolding [54–56]. While several recent studies support the direct interaction model [53,57–61], it is still unclear whether polar or apolar residues or the peptide backbone constitute the main interaction sites for urea. That the peptide backbone is an important interaction site for urea is now widely accepted [62–64]. However, some studies [52,58,59,61,65,66] stress the importance of urea-protein hydrogen bonds to polar residues. Scientists studies [60,67–75] support the importance of apolar urea protein contacts weakening the hydrophobic effect. Hence, more detailed insights into the interactions of a denaturant with amino acids are imperative to understand how denaturants work. Nowadays, ureas are widely recognised as highly useful templates upon which powerful organocatalytic systems [76–81], both mono- and bifunctional, can be constructed. However, the explosion of interest in these materials as potential catalysts is a relatively recent occurrence, particularly when one considers that the parent molecule (urea) was the product of arguably mankind’s first total synthesis in 1828. It is known that urea derivatives have been used as efficient Lewis-acidic catalysts for organic transformations due to effective H-bonds that are formed with the amide hydrogens. Due to the acidic hydrogens in urea compounds that contain electron-withdrawing substituents, stable cocrystals with a variety of proton acceptors, including carbonyl compounds, are readily formed [82]. Chiral urea derivatives have proven extraordinarily useful as catalysts for the enantioselective activation of imine and carbonyl derivatives toward nucleophilic addition [83]. However, despite the extensive application of these organic catalysts in asymmetric synthesis, their use in conjunction with organometallic reagents has yet to be developed. We sought to take advantage of the modular nature of these catalysts by incorporating a Lewis basic group in proximity to the urea moiety in order to promote the addition of organometallic reagents to CN bonds through dual activation [84]. Urea and its derivatives have been applied as catalysts for different reactions such as Claisen rearrangements and Diels-Alder reactions [85–88], respectively. Since, these materials have been shown to serve as active and versatile promoters of the addition of cyanide and silyl ketene acetals tonitrones [89], the Baylis-Hillman reaction [90], Friedel-Crafts typereactions [91], acetalisations [92], Claisen rearrangements [90,93], ring-openingreactions of oxiranes, [94,95] acyl Strecker reactions [96], tetrahydropyranylations [97] and imine reductions [98,99]. 2 Urea derivatives as hydrogen-bonding lewis-acidic organocatalysts Despite possessing a flat, readily modifiable and rotationally restricted structure with two mutually proximal NH bonds available for hydrogen bond donation, the potential of bis-aryl ureas and thioureas to serve as Lewis-acidic organocatalysts has only recently begun to be explored [86,100]. Given the accepted reaction mechanism (vide supra) and the known strong proclivity of aryl ureas and thioureas for carbonyl group [88,101] and (in particular) anion binding, [102] it appeared that these species would hold promise as novel, stable and readily accessible co-catalysts for the tertiary amine-promoted Baylis-Hillman reaction. In all the reactions in Section 2, urea derivatives act as lewis-acidic organocatalysts which in some cases refers to its mechanism. It has been demonstrated for the first time that bis-aryl ureas such as 1a–f can serve as efficient, stable and recyclable 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) compatible organocatalysts (Scheme 1 ) for the Baylis-Hillman reaction between a range of aromatic aldehydes 2 and methyl acrylate 3 in the absence of solvent (Scheme 2 ), and in this capacity are considerably more powerful mole per mole promoters of the reaction than either methanol or water. Preliminary results implicate a mechanism involving binding to a Zwitterionic intermediate/transition state, a more definitive understanding of which is necessary before further catalyst optimisation/derivatisation can proceed [90]. Reek, Meijer and co-workers developed a homogeneous catalyst that is anchored to a soluble dendrimer support using supramolecular interactions. The catalytic system 4 is noncovalently attached to the periphery of a urea adamantyl poly-(propylene imine) dendrimer 5 by ionic interactions in combination with multiple hydrogen bonds, which positions the guest ligand at the periphery of the dendrimer in a well-defined way (Scheme 3 ). The supramolecular dendrimeric system shows the same activity and selectivity in the Pd-catalyzed allylic amination as its unbound monomeric analogue, which indicates that every active site on the dendrimer acts as an independent catalyst and is easily accessible to the substrate (Scheme 4 ). Moreover, the catalyst is strongly bound such that the system can be operated in a continuous setup, which results in efficient separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture. Employing the concept of noncovalent anchoring simplifies the route toward sophisticated dendrimeric catalysts since ligand modification with the binding motive is straightforward. One of the limitations in dendrimeric catalysis is the troublesome synthesis of functionalized dendrimers, since quantitative coupling of ligands to the periphery is not always possible. With this strategy these problems are circumvented [103]. In 2005, An efficient and green procedure for the urea catalyzed Knoevenagel condensation was developed. In the presence of a catalytic ammount of urea, stoichiometric aldehyde and active methylene compound reacted under solvent-free conditions at 100 °C for 5–60 min to give nearly quantitative yield of product (Scheme 5 ). The possible mechanism of urea catalyzed Knoevenagel reaction has been proposed in Scheme 6 . At first, active methylene compound 8 reacts with urea 7 to form a six-membered cyclic intermediate 10. Because the active hydrogen of 8 is pulled strongly toward the more electronegative atoms, oxygen and nitrogen in 10, it is easier for 8 to add nucleophilically to the aldehyde. Along with the leaving of 11 intermediate 12 is obtained. There is equilibrium between 12 and 13. The 11 reacts with the 13 to remove one mole of H2O via ion pair 14 to afford the target product 9 and regenerate the urea [104]. Connon, Rozas and co-workers have shown for the first time that appropriately substituted N,N-diarylureas and thioureas 15a–k are capable of the efficient catalysis of the Corey-Chaykovsky reaction (CC reaction) involving the inexpensive trimethylsulfonium iodide 16 at ambient temperature (Scheme 7 ). Rather unusually, urea derivatives are clearly superior catalysts to their thiourea analogues in these processes. These catalyzed reactions are of wide scope with respect to the aldehyde component 17 and clean formation of the epoxide 18 is observed under optimal conditions a property which was exploited in the development of an epoxidation-Meinwald rearrangement process which allows convenient aromatic aldehyde homologation without requiring intermediate purification steps. Organocatalysed epoxidation of 19 followed by separation of the phases and addition of Cu(BF4)2 (25 mol%, hydrate) to the organic portion resulted in the isolation of the chain-extended phenyl acetaldehyde derivative 20 in good overall yield (Scheme 8 ) [105]. The authors therefore posited that (thio)urea derivatives could accelerate CC reactions under these conditions through the stabilization of developing negative charge on the oxygen heteroatom in the rate determining addition step [106] transition state (21, Fig. 1 ). In 2008, they synthesized novel N,N-aryl-tosyl ureas 22a and applied it for addition of 1,2-dimethylindole 24 to styrene oxide 23 under mild conditions (Scheme 9 ). Subsequent studies determined 22a to be compatible with a range of indole and epoxide substrates (including (E)-stilbene oxide) and found that relatively poor nucleophiles such as sterically and electronically deactivated anilines, thiophenol, and benzylalcohol could be efficiently and regioselectively added to oxiranes under mild conditions. They utilized computational DFT methods to evaluate the stabilities of hydrogen-bonded complexes between thio(urea) catalysts and three different electrophiles that incorporate Lewis-basic oxygen-based functionality. These data were then used to select a (thio)urea-electrophile pair predicted to be best suited for use in catalytic reactions in conjunction with a generic nucleophile. While this approach ignores the reaction transition state, it is rapidly executed, and the results can potentially be applied to a range of reactions involving a given electrophile and a number of various nucleophiles if discretion is exercised regarding nucleophile compatibility with the catalyst’s acidity. The results of these investigations strongly indicated that the previously unknown acidic urea-based catalyst 22a would potentially be able to serve as a more active promoter of addition reactions to epoxide derivatives than benchmark literature catalyst 22b. Synthesis and evaluation of 22a led to the validation of this computational study-guided design strategy 22a possessed unprecedented activity for a (thio)urea catalyst and promoted the addition of indole 24 to styrene oxide at room temperature under conditions that other (thio)urea derivatives (including 22a) did not. The catalyst was robust and of high synthetic utility: various styrene oxides (including a non terminal analogue) and indoles were tolerated, and (demonstrating the general applicability of the methodology) it was found that the catalyst was equally proficient in the promotion of CN, CS, and CO bond formation via the addition of weak nucleophiles to epoxides under conditions that do not give reactions in the absence of 22a. We are currently investigating the use of this strategy in the design of more complex bifunctional catalyst systems [94]. Nagasawa and co-workers have developed a new approach to the Morita-Baylis-Hillman reaction (MBH) utilizing a cooperative system of thio(urea) catalyst 25 and Lewis base. Chemoselective activation of carbonyl compounds 26,27 via hydrogen bonding to thiourea as a catalyst is the key to drastic rate acceleration of this reaction (Scheme 10 ). Based on our proposed reaction mechanism (Fig. 2 ), we postulated that if two active sites were linked with a suitable chiral spacer, the carbon-carbon bond forming process would take place more effectively owing to proximity effects, and simultaneously, asymmetric induction might be achieved [107]. Ureas as catalysts 28a–d were employed by the Mattson group, for the three component coupling of nitrodiazoesters 29, amines 30, and nucleophiles 31. This report includes evidence for the first organocatalytic activation of diazo compounds for participation in NH insertion reactions (Scheme 11 ). A plausible reaction pathway for this urea-catalyzed N-Hinsertion begins with coordination of boronate urea 28a to nitrodiazoester 29, giving rise to complex 32 (Scheme 12 ). The entropically favorable loss of nitrogen gas generates HBD stabilizes dcarbene complex 33, and a subsequent NH insertion reaction with aniline 34 ensues to yield intermediate 35 [108]. The extrusion of NO2 − from 35 generates iminium ion 36 and reintroduces the urea catalyst back into the cycle. Iminium ion 36 goes on to react with a nucelophile, such as a second equivalent of aniline, present in the reaction system affording the observed product 37. Alternate reaction pathways, such as those involving stepwise NH insertions, have not been explicitly ruled out at this time. Hydrogen bond doner (HBD)-generated carbenes are a new direction in the field of organic catalysis and we were interested to collect some evidence of potential organocarbene intermediate 33 accessed from α-nitro-α-diazo ester 29 in the presence of 28a. In general, itis less common to generate carbenes and carbenoids from α-nitro-α-diazo carbonyls than α-aryl/carbonyl-α-diazo carbonyls as there are only a few literature reports in this area [109,110]. Sakakura group have designed phosphate-urea cooperative high-turnover catalyst 38 for the highly selective bromocyclization of homogeranylarenes 39 to give bromocyclization products (40 and 4, X = Br) in 96–99% yield (Scheme 13 ). The introduction of a urea and bulky aryl groups in the catalyst successfully inhibits decomposition of the catalyst and the generation of by-products. The present method could also be applied to the bromocyclization of 2-geranylphenols. The authors proposed a mechanism of the triaryl phosphite catalyzed bromocyclization of 39a and the generation of undesired dibromide 42a (Scheme 14 ). Bromophosphonium ion 43 is presumably generated as an active species via the nucleophilic activation of N-bromosuccinimide (NBS) by the triaryl phosphite catalyst [111] (step 1). Regioselective bromination of the terminal double bond of 39a with 43 (step 2) followed by cyclization gives the desired bromocyclization products 40a and 41a. Based on these results, it was proposed that electron-withdrawing groups on the phosphine atom increase the reactivity of 43, and that step 39 is rate determining. In another pathway, phosphonium bromide 44 might be generated [112] through the nucleophilic attack of the succinimide anion to the bromophosphonium ion 43. The reaction of 44 with bromonium ion 45 should give undesired dibromide 42a and succinimide. But this step does not give that in the presence of catalyst 38. A proposal for the active species generated from NBS and phosphate-urea combination catalyst 38 is shown in Scheme 15 . The activation of NBS with 38 presumably generates bromophosphoniumion 46, in which the succinimide anion might interact with the urea group through hydrogen bonding [113,114]. This hydrogenbonding interaction in 46 might successfully inhibits the nucleophilic attack of succinimide anion to the bromophosphoniumion and the formation of phosphonium bromide 47. Therefore, the generation of dibromide 42a might be suppressed [115]. A green protocol for efficient synthesis of β-functionalized ketonic derivatives 51 is achieved with the combination of ultrasound and the deep eutectic solvent (DES) choline chloride-urea 48 [ChCl:urea (1:2)] that was reported by Shankarling group. Under optimized conditions, nucleophilic attack of active methylene 50 on α,β-unsaturated ketones 49 gives the conjugate addition product in the short span of 40–50 min with an excellent yield of 89–95% (Scheme 16 ). The experimental procedure is very simple, easy to set up, solvent free and completely eliminates the use of any toxic metal catalyst. The use of ChCl:urea as a biodegradable, recyclable and reusable catalyst (up to five cycles) further increases the scope of the developed methodology. It is observed that ChCl: urea (1:2) proves to be an efficient catalyst for synthesis of β-substituted ketones. Hence, a tentative mechanistic route indicating the important role of the ChCl:urea (1:2) system is demonstrated in Scheme 17 . The stronger hydrogen-bonding capabilities of ChCl:urea(1:2) results in an oxyanion intermediate which on further proton abstraction gives the final addition product [116]. Zhao and co-workers developed urea-pyridine bridged periodic mesoporous organosilica 54 (PMO) to prevent the unwanted self-recognition and aggregation of urea-based catalytic center by spatial isolation, unleashing its HBD organocatalytic activity along with cooperative effect from the pyridine unit for efficient Henry reaction using various substituted benzaldehydes and nitromethane 55 to produce β-Nitro alcohols 56 (Scheme 18 B). Catalyst 54 was synthesized (Scheme 18A) through the condensation between the amino group of compound 52 and the isocyanato unit of compound 53. The urea-pyridine bridged PMO catalyst presents high structural stability and high catalytic recyclability. Through the immobilization of the urea-pyridine conjugate in PMO, the self-dimerization of the urea unit has been prohibited, thus enhancing its catalytic activity. Additional base is not needed, as the pyridine unit in Urea/PMO serves as the base to trigger the deprotonation of nitromethane. The developed Urea/PMO catalyst has shown high structural stability and recyclability, presenting a new class of heterogeneous organocatalyst for potential practical uses [117]. The catalytic activity of urea-, metal- and organic acid-based/choline chloride deep eutectic solvents/organocatalysts 57 were investigated for the synthesis of 3-aminoimidazo-fused heterocycles 60 via a one-pot domino reaction of an 2-amino heterocycles 58, an aldehyde, and isocyanide 59 (Scheme 19 ). The urea-based/choline chloride system exhibited significant catalytic activity for the reaction and could be reused in four consecutive reactions with no considerable loss in catalytic activity. The advantages of this method are operational simplicity, green medium, deep eutectic solvents (DES) recoverability, short reaction times and high yields [118]. HBD catalysts enable a variety of formal insertion reactions of diazo compounds too. The role of the catalyst in the reaction system may vary depending on several factors, including the nucleophilicity of the diazo compound and the acidity of the insertion partner. Ureas and phosphoric acid derivatives can offer complementary reactivity patterns when selected as catalysts for selected OH and SH insertion reactions of aryl- and diazo-substituted esters that was reported by Burtoloso group. Early on, their investigations led them to the unanticipated finding that difluoroboronate urea 61 enabled the NH insertion/arylation of α-nitro-α-diazo esters 63 (as electrophilic diazo compound), giving rise to glycines 64 in good to excellent yields (53–91%, Scheme 20 A) [109], and double arylation insertion of 63 produce 65 in excellent yields (Scheme 20B). In other initial study, a variety of carboxylic acids were found to operate as insertion partners with electron rich α-aryl-α-diazo esters 66 (as nucleophilic diazo compound) to afford 67 in high yields (Scheme 20C). The substrate scope was even more broad with respect to the S-H insertion: arenethiols, alkanethiols, and thioacids all reacted well with electron-rich α-aryl-α-diazo esters 66. Several diazo compounds were prepared and subjected to an insertion reaction with thiophenol catalyzed by 61. As a general trend, the more nucleophilic diazo compounds afforded higher yields of product. The most electron-rich dimethylamino-substituted diazo ester 66a gave the highest yield of insertion product 68a (92%). (Scheme 20D) [119]. Ye Group disclosed a stereoselective Koenigs-Knorr glycosylation reaction catalyzed by urea 69. The activation of glycosyl chlorides or bromides 70 by urea through a hydrogen-bond interaction, followed by glycosylation, afforded the coupled products 72 smoothly without the use of heavy metals (Scheme 21 ). Excellent yields and high anomeric selectivity were obtained in most cases. The troublesome α-stereoselectivity of glycosylation when using perbenzylated glucosyldonors could be greatly improved by the addition of tri-(2,4,6-trimethoxyphenyl) phosphine (TTMPP). The noncovalent interactions of donor with urea or TTMPP were supported by 1H NMR analysis and some control experiments [120]. Pd/HY zeolite catalyst modified by ammonium fluoride and urea (Pd/NH4F-Urea-HY) was efficient applied in acetylenehydrochlorination reaction (Scheme 22 ). The modification of NH4F and Urea in Pd/HY catalyst could significantly enhance the catalytic performance, maintaining a good catalytic performance with acetylene conversion (99%) and selectivity to vinyl chloride (99%) for over 8 h. It was illustrated that the enhanced catalytic performance was attributed to the NH4F and urea modification, which decreased the Pd loss, changed the surface acidity of catalysts, prevented the Pd reduction and inhibited the carbon deposition [121]. A facile one-pot, multicomponent protocol for the synthesis of 6-oxo-pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole 78 and pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole-4,4′-diacetate 79 derivatives using a urea catalyst 73 is reported. The first transformation proceeds via a three component reaction of ethyl acetoacetate 74, a hydrazine 75, 3-oxo-pentanedioic acid dimethyl ester 76 and another transformation proceeds via the same three component and malononitrile 77 (Scheme 23 ). The bifunctional nature of urea means that it catalyzes many steps in this transformation, including domino Knoevenagel condensation, Michael addition, and ringopening and closing reactions. This synthetic method has several advantages, including good yield, simple work-up, harmless by-products, and simple purification [122]. An efficient and green synthesis of pyrazolyl-2,4-thiazolidinediones/pyrazolyl-2-iminothiazolidine-4-ones 84 has been developed using urea/thiourea 80 as catalyst. Two methods (A and B) have been introduced for the synthesis of these compounds. Method A performed well for the condensation of pyrazole-4-carboxaldehydes 81 with 2-iminothiazolidin-4-one 82a and with 2,4-thiazolidinedione 82b at 110 °C for 16–20 min to furnish (Z)-5-((1,3-diphenyl-1Hpyrazol-4-yl)methylene)thiazolidine-2,4-diones 84 in excellent yields. In method B, the pyrazole-4-carboxaldehydes 81 were condensed with urea/thiourea at 110 °C for 10 min to give key intermediates 83 which were later condensed with 82a and 82b to afford 84 via the elimination of urea/thiourea rather than the formation of a Biginelli product (Scheme 24 ). These two protocols are inexpensive, eco-friendly and high yielding to provide the final products [123]. Mild combination of nitro urea, derived from urea nitrate, and silica sulfuric acid (SiO2OSO3H) might act as an efficient oxidizing media, which could be able to oxidize different types of heterocyclic compounds including 1,4-dihydropyridines and urazoles (Scheme 25 ). Furthermore, this method exhibits substrate versatility, non-toxic conditions and mild reaction conditions, and easy and clean work-up of products [124]. 3 Urea salts derivatives as hydrogen-bonding organocatalysts N-Nitrosation of amines is an important and well established reaction in organic synthesis. In the reaction given in Section 3, urea derivatives act as hydrogen-bonding organocatalysts which the mechanism of action is similar to Section 2. Therefore, Zolfigol and co-workers have investigated a number of different reaction conditions based upon the in situ generation of HNO2 by relatively strong inorganic acidic salt (i.e. Al(HSO4)3, PKa ≈ 1) or organic acidic salts (85b and 85c) and sodium nitrite and wet SiO2 (50% w/w) in dichloromethane for the nitrosation of secondary amines 86 (Scheme 26 ). They reported a simple, cheap and chemoselective method for the effective nitrosation of secondary amines under mild and heterogeneous conditions. The cheapness and the availability of the reagents, easy and clean work-up, chemoselectivity and high yields make this method attractive for organic chemists. This simple procedure is highly selective, and contamination by deprotection and C-nitrosation side-products are avoided [125]. 4 Urea derivatives as basic organocatalysts In 2014, Brahmachari and co-workers have developed a very simple, facile, energy efficient, and conveniently practical method for easy access to a wide range of pharmaceutically interesting functionalized 2-amino-3-cyano-4H-pyrans and pyran-annulated heterocycles in the presence of urea as a novel organo-catalyst via one-pottandem Knoevenagel-cyclocondensation of aldehydes, malononitrile, and CH-activated acids 88a–g in aqueous ethanol at room temperature. Mild reaction conditions, excellent yields, operational simplicity, absence of tedious separation procedures, clean reaction profiles, energy-efficiency, and high atom-economy, as well as the use of inexpensive and environmentally benign catalysts are the key advantages of the present method. Moreover, reusability of the reaction media is an added advantage to this protocol. Following this protocol, it was possible to synthesize 2-amino-3-cyano-pyrano[3,2-c]chromen-5(4H)-ones (89aa–89al), 2-amino-3-cyano-pyrano[4,3-b]pyran-5(4H)-ones (89ba–89be), 2-amino-3-cyano-7,8-dihydro-4H-chromen-5(6H)-one (89ca–89cr), 1H-pyrano[2,3-d]pyrimidine-2, 4(3H,5H)-diones (89da–89dd), 2-amino-3-cyano-5,10-dioxo-5,10-dihydro-4H-benzo[g]chromenes (89ea-89ec), 2-amino-3-cyano-4Hpyrans (89fa–89fh), and 1,4-dihydropyrano[2,3-c]pyrazoles (89ga–89gb) Urea derivatives in the reaction given in Section 4, act as basic organocatalysts which the mechanism is presented below (Scheme 27 ). The authors proposed a mechanism in Scheme 28 for the formation of pyran-annulated heterocycles under the reaction conditions where urea acts as a base. It is supposed that the Knoevenagel intermediate 91 formed in situ is attacked by the enolate of the CH-activated acid 92 giving rise to the adduct 93/94 which eventually undergoes ring closure to afford the desired product 89 (Scheme 28) [126]. 5 Urea anions derivatives as organocatalyst Aliphatic polyesters and polycarbonates are class of biorenewable, biocompatible, and biodegradable materials. One of the most powerful methods for accessing these materials is the ring-opening polymerization (ROP) of cyclic monomers. Here we report that the deprotonation of ureas generates a class of versatile catalysts that are simultaneously fast and selective for the living ring-opening polymerization of several common monomers, including lactide 96, δ-valerolactone 97, ε-caprolactone 98, a cyclic carbonate 99, and a cyclic phosphoester 100 (Scheme 29 ) that its mechanism is shown in Scheme 30 . On the basis of the kinetic data, the mechanism in Scheme for the ring-opening polymerization of ε-caprolactone(CL) is proposed. Reaction of a neutral urea with potassium alkoxide or KH generates a urea anion that can reversibly activate the alcohol initiator or polymer chain-end by H-bonding. The decrease in rate observed with excess urea can be attributed to the reversible formation of dimers (or oligomers) [127] of the urea anion with neutral urea, which are proposed to be inactive for polymerization. The productive ring-opening step is proposed to be facilitated by the bifunctional activation of the alcohol through H-bonding to the anionic portion of the urea anion and of the lactone through H-bonding to the NH of the urea anion in intermediate RC. Nucleophilic attack by the H-bond activated alcohol leads to ring-opening and regeneration of an alcohol/urea anion adduct (Scheme 30). Spanning several orders of magnitude, the reactivity of several diaryl urea anions correlated to the electron-withdrawing substituents on the aryl rings. With the appropriate urea anions, the polymerizations reached high conversions (∼90%) at room temperature within seconds (1–12 s), yielding macromolecules with narrow molecular weight distributions (D = 1.06–1.14). These versatile catalysts are simple to prepare, easy to use, and exhibit a range of activities that can be tuned for the optimal performance of a broad range of monomers [128]. 6 Urea-metal coupling derivatives as organocatalysts Urea derivatives hydrogen-bond donating catalysts are good catalysts for the valuable organic transformations. Usually urea derivatives undergo self-recognition and aggregation during the homogeneous catalytic process. To avoid this, recently the new approach of incorporation of urea moieties into metal-organic framework (MOF) is developed (Section 6). The mechanism of action of described catalysts based on hydrogen bond donating and shown in one case (Scheme 37). In 2008, active Pd nanoclusters could be easily prepared with high yields on urea modified siliceous mesocellular foam (MCF). They were formed by the reduction of Pd(OAc)2, and were stabilized by the urea ligands on the MCF surface (Scheme 31 ). The ultralarge mesopores of MCF facilitated reactions involving bulky substrates. The resulting Pd/Urea-MCF catalyst demonstrated excellent activity for transfer hydrogenation, hydrogenation and CC coupling reactions, and were superior to commercially available 10 wt% Pd/C or polymer supported Pd-Encat (Scheme 32 ). The facile synthesis and novel design of supported metal catalyst described herein might be widely applied to derive metallic nanoclusters supported on modified MCF for a wide variety of catalytic reactions in chemical syntheses [129]. 1n 2012, urea-containing MOF 109, was synthesized from a tetracarboxylate strut 107, 4,4′-bipyridine 108, and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O as a heterogeneous catalyst by Roberts group (Scheme 33 ). Ureas are well-known for self-recognition and aggregation behavior, resulting in loss of catalytic competency. The catalyst spatial isolation achievable in a porous MOF environment suggests a potentially general solution. The combination of a symmetrical urea tetracarboxylate structure, 4,4′-bipyridine, and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O under solvothermal conditions afforded a new microporous MOF (NU-601). This material is indeed an effective hydrogen-bond-donor catalyst for Friedel-Crafts reactions between pyrroles 110 and nitroalkenes 111, whereas a homogeneous urea is much less competent (Scheme 34 ). The higher rates of reaction of small substrates relative to larger ones with NU-601 strongly suggest that catalysis primarily occurs within the pores of this new material rather than on its exterior. To the best of their knowledge, this approach is the first example of specific engineering of successful hydrogen-bonding catalysis in to a MOF material [130]. Two pillared MOFs, including urea-functional groups are introduced by Tehrani and co-workers in 2015. Herein, urea functional groups were incorporated into the MOF backbone by preparing urea-ditopic ligand. These frameworks (TMU-18 112a and TMU-19 112b) were fabricated using the synthesized urea-containing ligand 113, 4,4′-bipyridine 114 (bipy) and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane 115 (bpe), respectively, using zinc nitrate as metal source (Scheme 35 ) [131]. Furthermore, their potential talent as organocatalysts was evaluated in the regioselective methanolysis of epoxides (Scheme 36 ). Urea-functionalized porphyrin catalysts containing a cavity, which are used for the processive epoxidation of polymers, are thoroughly characterized and their binding properties and other supramolecular features disclosed (Fig. 2). Intramolecular coordination of the urea side chains to the metal center of the porphyrin moiety is unveiled through NMR, IR, UV, and fluorescence spectroscopy studies. This intramolecular coordination appears to be essential in order to facilitate catalysis in apseudo-rotaxane fashion, i.e. by preventing the use of excess of bulky axial ligands. The current investigation provides information on how to modulate in a dynamic fashion the catalytic activity of supramolecular systems, which is of interest for the design of increasingly efficient processive catalysts. Previously Elemans group reported that Mn-Tetrakis[3-(3-ethylureido)propoxy]porphyrinClip (MnUPC) is a better epoxidation catalyst than Mn-Tetrakis porphyrin (MnP) and this compound, in contrast to the latter one, requires no axial pyridine ligand for activation [132]. It was tentatively explained this feature from the fact that the carbonyl groups of the urea functions of MnUPC were coordinated to the metal center making that no additional axial ligand is needed. All the studies on the zinc derivative Zn-Tetrakis[3-(3-ethylureido)propoxy]porphyrinClip(ZnUPC) presented in this study, confirmed this explanation. They clearly showed that the urea functions on the porphyrin roof of this compound bind to the metal center and hence can take over the role of a pyridine ligand as the metal-activating species for catalysis. This conclusion is further supported by the NMR measurements and binding studies of the precursor of ZnUPC, Zn-Tetrakis{o-3-[(tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino]propoxy}porphyrinClip (ZnBocPC), which also possesses carbonyl groups located on the porphyrin roof that can coordinate to the zinc center. Host ZnUPC can thus be regarded as a double “picket fence” porphyrin, with one side shielded by a guest binding cavity and the other side protected by a pseudo-cavity formed by metal binding urea groups that are linked by hydrogen bonds. This feature makes the manganese analogue of ZnUPC an ideal processive catalyst for the epoxidation of polymer substrates, as confirmed by the authors of previous studies [133]. The authors have demonstrated that through the incorporation of the selfassociative HBD organocatalyst into a MOF, one can “turn on” novel catalytic activity not seen in the free organocatalyst. It was demonstrated that this biodegradable and green catalyst is very active and selective, and choline chloride and urea showed a synergetic effect in promoting these reactions. After reaction, the solid catalyst and the products could be separated easily because the IL was insoluble in the products, and the catalyst was reusable. The origin of the high catalytic efficiency and the reaction mechanism were also discussed. The possible mechanism is suggested and shown schematically in Scheme 39. The chloride anion (combining with two urea molecules) of the IL opens the epoxy ring, which is activated by the choline cation through hydrogen bonding, to give the intermediate 121. Then, the intermediate further reacts with CO2 to form the corresponding cyclic carbonate 122 and regenerate the catalyst (Scheme 40) [135]. 7.2 Urea coupling with ionic liquid and metal as catalyst Sun and his group synthesized [urea-Zn]I2 catalyst 123 for efficient conversion of carbon dioxide to cyclic carbonates (Scheme 41 ). Advantages of this reaction are low cost, moisture-stability, facile synthesis and efficiently bifunctional properties reported herein displayed the exceptionally outstanding features for efficient conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates [136]. 8 Chiral urea derivatives as catalysts in enantioselective reactions α-Amino acid derivatives are broadly useful chiral building blocks with especially important applications in complex natural product and combinatorial syntheses. In all the reactions in Section 8, chiral urea derivatives act as organocatalysts in enantioselective reactions which in some cases refers to its mechanism. Here, Jacobsen and co-workers reported a catalyst 124 that is a derivative of the urea and display high enantioselectivity in the reactions (Fig. 3 ). The asymmetric Strecker reaction of imine 125 and HCN, catalyzed by nonmetal catalysts 124 provides direct access to a diverse range of unnatural aliphatic and aromatic substituted amino acid 126 precursors in high enantiomeric excess (ee) [Scheme 42 ]. Consistent with the notion that these catalysts are enzyme-like, all structural components of catalyst 124 have been shown to be vital for both reactivity and enantioselectivity and thus appear to function cooperatively [137]. This catalyst was applied for Strecker reaction of selected aldimines and ketoimines 127 (Scheme 43 ) and there was an improvements in enantioselectivity of products 128 in the presence of catalyst 124 and was compared with similar catalysts [100]. The more electrophilic benzaldehyde N-tert-butoxycarbonyl- (N-Boc) imine 130 underwent reaction with trimethylsilyl ketene acetal 129 in the presence of catalyst 124 to afford the desired Mannich adduct in 47% ee (Scheme 44 ). The rate of the uncatalyzed racemic reaction was found to be significant (roughly 45% conversion in the absence of catalyst under the same reaction conditions), indicating that the pathway catalyzed by catalyst 124 proceeded with very high enantioselectivity [138]. Jacobsen and co-workers in 2005, found catalyst 124 which provided excellent enantio- and diastereoselectivity at 0 °C in Nitro-Mannich reactions (Scheme 45 ). After a screen of additives, it was discovered that the addition of powdered 4-Å molecular sieves improved the reproducibility of the process and provided a more diastereoselective reaction [139]. Nagasawa and co-workers have designed and synthesized the new type of chiral urea 132 (Scheme 46 ) as a catalyst for the hetero-Michael reaction between γˍcrotonolactone 133 and pyrrolidine 134 to yield 135 (Scheme 47 ). The viability of the general concept of a bifunctional quasi Lewis acid-Bronsted base catalyst was reflected in the catalytic performance of 136a: Initial experiments with the phenylalanine-derived azlactone 137a and methanol as the nucleophile afforded >60% ee in the presence of 5 mol% of the catalyst 136a. The screening of different alcohols revealed that the conversion rates drop sharply as the steric demand of the alcohol increases; the highest rate was observed with methanol. As allyl alcohol gave the best enantioselectivity, this nucleophile was used in all further experiments. Of the solvents examined, toluene and fluorobenzene proved optimal. Consistent with their mechanistic picture (Scheme 49), no reaction occurred in solvents that act as H-bond acceptors, such as tetrahydrofuran (THF) (Scheme 48 ). A substrate-catalyst interaction is expected to occur by hydrogen bonding of the quasi Lewis acidic urea moiety to the azlactone carbonyl group [22–24] (Scheme 49). It is described a broadly applicable organocatalytic method for the dynamic kinetic resolution of azlactones with the highest levels of enantioselectivity reported to date. The catalysts can be prepared easily and have a modular structure. Therefore, our method should be readily adaptable for the generation of other enantiomerically pure amino acids (Scheme 49) [141]. A systematic investigation into the effects of the relative stereochemistry at C8 and C9 of these materials on catalyst performance has implicated bifunctional catalysis and revealed that C9 epimeric catalysts are remarkably more efficacious in terms of rate and selectivity than analogues of “natural” cinchona alkaloid stereochemistry. Highly active 9-epi-DHQT and 9-epimer-dihydroquinidine tiourea (9-epi-DHQDT) have been identified as efficient and enantioselective catalysts with substrate-scope and selectivity profiles on a par with current benchmark literature systems and can be conveniently employed at relatively low catalyst loadings (0.5–5 mol%) [142]. Wennemers et al. started their investigations by examining the reactivity of malonic acid half-thioesters 174 (MAHTs) with nitrostyrene in the presence of different bases. Sub stoichiometric amounts (20 mol%) of tertiaryamines (for example, NEt3, Hunigʼs base, quinuclidine) or imidazole in THF led to the formation of the desired conjugate addition product, but in yields lower than 15%; the main product was decarboxylated MAHT. These initial experiments also showed that the stability of MAHTs depends largely on the solvent. Decarboxylation occurs in polar protic solvents within hours, while the stability is significantly higher in, for example, CH2Cl2, THF, and other ethers. Thus, these initial trials revealed that there is a subtle balance between product formation and nonproductive decarboxylation, thus demonstrating that controling the reactivity of the MAHTs is a challenging task. The activation and reaction of MAHTs is achieved by polyketide synthases (PKSs), which lack metal ions and have in common the amino acids cysteine (Cys) histidine (His), and asparagine (Asn; or another histidine) in their active sites [150]. Within the catalytic triad, the His-Asn motive is responsible for activating the coenzyme A (CoA)-bound deprotonated MAHT that reacts upon decarboxylation with a second Cys-bound thioester (Fig. 4 ). This inspired us to address the question of whether metal-free organocatalysts can catalyze addition reactions of MAHTs to electrophiles [151–153]. Since PKSs accomplish the activation of MAHTs by coordination through Asn and protonated His residues [150], the authors speculated that bifunctionality within the catalyst structure would be the key to efficient catalysis. A basic site was envisioned to allow for deprotonation of the MAHT and, together with a second coordination site, for orienting the MAHT and the nitroolefin in a chiral environment (Fig. 4). Since urea and thiourea functionalities are known to be excellent coordination sites for carbonyl moieties [154] they chose to use urea-functionalized cinchona alkaloids to evaluate their catalyst design. Cinchona alkaloid derivatives 173a–h, which have previously been used as catalysts for a range of different reactions [154,155], were prepared and their catalytic activity tested in the reaction of MAHT 174 with nitrostyrene as a first test substrate. They were pleased to observe both catalyst turnover and enantioselectivity when compounds 173a–h was added to the reaction of MAHT and nitrostyrene. Epiquinineurean 174 proved to be the most active and selective catalyst: Mixing a 2:1 mixture of MAHT 174 and nitrostyrene in THF afforded the 1,4-addition product 175 in 94% yield and 63% ee within 24 h (Scheme 61 ) [156]. Using N-sulfinyl urea 212 catalysis, a method has been developed for the asymmetric synthesis of biologically important γ-amino acids with a high level of efficiency, practicality and unprecedented control of multiple stereocenters. This method is based upon the highly enantio- and diastereoselective addition of cyclohexyl Meldrum’s acid 213 as an easily deprotectable monocarboxylic acid equivalent. The addition to both β-substituted and α,β-disubstituted nitroalkenes using N-sulfinyl urea organocatalyst 212 is described (Scheme 79 ). This method is not only the first example of the highly enantioselective addition of Meldrum’s acid derivatives to nitroalkenes, but also provides the first example of the organocatalytic addition of any type of carbon nucleophile to acyclic α,β-disubstituted nitroalkenes to set both the α- and β-stereocenters in acyclic products with high enantio and diastereoselectivity. Experimental evidence suggests that the bifunctional H-bond donor/H-bond acceptor character of the catalysts appears to be a key for the dual activation of the reactants, leading to enantioenriched products via a highly ordered complex that explains the observed stereochemistry. Assuming that just one good H-bond acceptor moiety is required to activate the hydrazone 233, this hybrid catalyst 232 should behave as 231a/231c, not as 231b/231d. In fact, the enantioselectivity reached with this catalyst matched that obtained with the bis-urea 231a, affording the product with similar enantiomeric excess (88% ee at −30 °C) and in a slightly shorter reaction time of 64 h, which accounts for the slightly better H-bond donor properties of the thiourea moiety. It was suggested that one of the urea carbonyl groups in these catalysts might serve as a H-bond acceptor for the hydrazone NH group, providing an additional interaction that could hardly be effected by bis-thiourea derivatives 231b/231d.18 This hypothesis led to the proposal of a stereochemical model where the second urea moiety activates the carbonyl substrate 234 in a ternary complex A, which is preorganized for the attack of the azomethine carbon to the Re-face of the ketone carbonyl, leading to a zwitterionic intermediate B that releases the product 235a and the catalyst 231a or 231c (Scheme 88 ) [175]. Enantioselective bromolactonizations can also be performed on conjugated (Z)-enynes 237 as shown by the Tang group. These reactions do not belong directly to the class of enantioselective electrophilic additions to alkenes, but are closely related. Tang et al. showed that chichona alkaloidderived urea catalyst 236 can be used in combination with NBS to achieve high asymmetric inductions (Scheme 89 ). The authors suggest that the urea catalyst plays a bifunctional role activating the electrophilic NBS as well as the carboxylic acid of the substrate. Bromination of the carbon-carbon triple bond followed by vinylogous addition of the carboxylic acid group would then provide the product. Urea-based catalysts were also employed by the Jacobsen group, this time to catalyze iodolactonizations. They showed that chiral ureas based on trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane are selective catalysts for iodolactonizations when used in combination with the iodine source N-iodo-4-fluorophthalimide 240 and a catalytic amount of iodine (Scheme 90 a) [114]. Very good enantioselectivities were obtained for the 6-exo cyclization of 5-hexenoic acids 239 if the reactions were conducted at low temperature. A highly enantioselective 5-exo iodolactonization of a pentenoic acid was also reported after the reoptimization of the reaction conditions for this substrate class. The authors suggest, based on spectroscopic hints, that the urea catalyst 238 is initially reacting with N-iodophthalimide to form a complex or ion pair in which the urea unit is hydrogen bonded to the phthalimide and the iodine atom is transferred to the tertiary amine of the catalyst (Scheme 90b). This is followed by the iodination/cyclization of the substrate, where the catalyst-phthalimide complex plays a bifunctional role: iodination of the alkene and activation/deprotonation of the carboxylic acid group for the cyclization and produce product 241 [176]. Ellman and co-workers have demonstrated that a sulfinyl urea organocatalyst 242 promotes the first highly enantioselective addition of thioacetic acid to aromatic and aliphatic β-substituted nitroalkenesas well as a range of cyclic nitroalkenes to introduce two stereocenters (Scheme 91 ). Additionally, the role of the sulfinyl group was investigated by replacing it with a variety of aryl and sulfonyl groups. Of 15 urea catalysts synthesized and tested, none displayed comparable selectivity to the sulfinyl catalysts, highlighting the importance of the sulfinyl group in attaining high enantioselectivity in the thioacetic acid addition. This reaction can serve as a general method for preparing chiral 1,2-aminothiols in compounds of pharmaceutical interest, as demonstrated by the expedient synthesis of R-sulconazole in 96% ee and good overall yield [172]. A type of cooperative catalyst 243 that features urea H-bonding and a cobalt center has been developed for anti-selective asymmetric nitroaldol 245 reactions (Henry reactions) by Hong group (Scheme 92 ). During the course of the study, the authors were intrigued by the possibility that the [(bisurea-salen)Co] catalyst might enable the antiparallel transition state for the Henry reaction, either by bimetallic dual activation or by H-bond/metal bifunctional activation (Scheme 93 ). The urea H-bonds play a crucial role in the dramatic improvement in reaction yield, enantioselectivity, and antidiastereoselectivity. The use of the urea-cobalt bifunctional catalyst successfully extends the substrate scope of antiselective Henry reactions to previously unexplored aldehydes [177]. A method for the asymmetric reduction of β-amino nitroolefins by using S-chiral N-sulfinyl ureas 246a–c as bifunctional catalyst and trichlorosilane as reducing agent have developed by Liu group (Scheme 94 ). A broad range of products was obtained in high yield and excellent enantioselectivity. The product can easily be transformed into practically useful diamine and amino acid derivatives. This method provide a new approach to chiral β-aminonitroalkanes 247 in high yield and excellent enantioselectivity (93–99% yield, 95–96% ee) and it also offers a new strategy for the design and implementation of efficient bifunctional catalysts, particularly for the asymmetric reduction through hydrosilylation. They envisioned that if all the chiral-directing, acidifying, and Lewis base activating functions of the S-chiral sulfinyl group could be fully utilized, N-sulfinyl ureas with a relatively simple structure might serve as efficient catalyst to address the asymmetric reduction of β-amino nitroolefins through hydrosilylationin a new dual-functional activation pattern (Scheme 95 ) [178–180]. Ureas 248a–d operate as catalysts for the preparation of highly substituted oxazinanes 251 produced from the reaction of nitrones 250 with nitrocyclopropane carboxylates 249. This is the first report of nitrocyclopropane carboxylates participating in formal [3 + 3] cycloaddition reactions (Scheme 96 ). The oxazinane products can be isolated in high enantiomeric access via chirality transfer of an enantioenriched nitrocyclopropane. The urea-activation of nitrocyclopropane carboxylates fits into a larger ongoing research program that focused on interesting reactivity patterns accessed via hydrogen bond donor catalysis. Chirality transfer was observed from an enantioenriched nitrocyclopropane carboxylate. Specifically, the subjection of enantioenriched 249a to the optimized reaction conditions gave rise to 251a as a 2:1 mixture of enantioenriched (91% ee) diastereomers. The major diastereomer 251a' was found to have the two aromatic rings and the nitro group cis while 251a” was epimeric at the carbon bearing the identification of the two diastereomers isolated in combination with the observed chirality transfer, led authors to a plausible stepwise reaction pathway for the transformation (Scheme 97 ). After initial activation of the nitrocyclopropane carboxylate with the urea catalyst, the nitrone undergoes nucleophilic addition with inversion of configuration giving rise to species 253 and 254. Evidence for inversion of configuration was on the major enantiomer of the oxazinane 252. The stereochemical outcome of the reaction may result from the cyclization of 253 and 254 through chair-like transition states (Scheme 98 ) [181]. Jacobsen group in 2013, have achieved the enantioselective synthesis of chiral iodoamines 257 by a urea-catalysed iodocyclization of easilyaccessed alkenyl trichloroacetimidates 256 (Scheme 98). This approach to enantioselective iodoamination represents a potentially general platform for electrophilic alkene functionalization that may be readily extended to other onium ions. The electrophilic iodinating agent, N-iodosuccinimide (NIS), has no detectable solubility in the reaction medium used for the catalytic iodoamination reaction (toluene, −40 °C to–50 °C). This suggests a basis for the high sensitivity of enantioinduction on the substituents on the salicyaldimine. The authors propose that the urea Schiff-base catalysts promote the iodocyclization reaction by acting as a neutral phase transfer agent. This pathway is reminiscent of the chiral phosphate anionphase transfer catalysis that has recently been implicated in related halocyclizations [182], although the solubilization mechanism is clearly quite different in the present case (Scheme 99 ) [183]. By using the optimized catalyst 262o, selectivities up to 93:7 could be obtained by using 263 2 mol% catalyst (Scheme 104 ). The transformation of (3R,4S)-1-benzyl-4-phenylpyrrolidine-3-carboxylic acid 270 [188] was conducted via a Curtius rearrangement [189] [3,5-bis(tri-fluoromethyl)aniline] 271, to give catalyst 268 in a 40% yield [190]. Bis-camphorsulfonyl urea 272a, a newly developed hydrogen bonding catalyst, was evaluated in an enantioselective Friedel Crafts reaction between nitroalkenes and pyrrole 273 (Scheme 108 ). Narayana and co-workers observed that complexation of the sulfonyl urea with a sodium cation enhanced the selectivity of reactions in comparison to reactions performed with urea alone. To understand the role of sodium cation, they performed Infrared and Raman spectroscopic studies. The detailed band assignment of the molecule was made by calculating spectra using Density Functional theory. Their studies suggest that the binding of the cation takes place through the oxygen atoms of carbonyl and sulfonyl groups. Natural Bond Orbital (NBO) analysis shows the expected charge distribution after sodium binding. The changes in the geometrical parameter and charge distribution are in line with the experimentally observed spectral changes. Based on these studies, the authors conclude that binding of the sodium cation changes the conformation of the sulfonyl urea to bring the chiral camphor groups closer to the incipient chiral center [191]. A flexible and highly telescoped synthesis strategy for a structurally diverse library of chiral cyclohexanediamine-based urea-containing quaternary ammonium salts 274a, 274b was developed. The catalysts were successfully employed in asymmetric Michael addition reactions and a new powerful aldol-initiated cascade reaction of glycine Schiff bases 275 with methylacrylate 276 with high enantioselectivities and good to excellent yields (Scheme 109 ) [192]. Vesely et al. designed and prepared bifunctional (thio) urea-tertiary phosphine organocatalysts 278a–e and 279a–b, which were readily available from naturally occurring biomolecules such as d-glucose, glycine, l-alanine, and l-valine (Scheme 110 ). The efficiency of the organocatalysts was demonstrated in the asymmetric Morita-Baylis-Hillman (MBH) reaction of aromatic aldehydes with acrylates (Scheme 111 ). The MBH products 280 were obtained in good yields and with high enantioselectivities. The l-valine-derived bifunctional thiourea-phosphine catalyst 278c, was found to be highly efficient in the MBH reaction, giving the MBH adducts with good to high yields (up to 85%) and high enantioselectivities (up to 87% ee) [193]. Jiang group have developed an enantioselective stereoablative carboxylation of 3-bromooxindoles 282 with MAHTs 283 and a series of commercially available carboxylic acids 284 to produce chiral 3-substituted 3-carboxylates-2-oxindoles 285, 286 and 3-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindoles 287, by employing a L-tertiary amine based urea-tertiary amine bifunctional catalyst 281 (Scheme 112 ) [194]. The current method provides an efficient and practical strategy to synthesize a broad scope of chiral 3-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindoles 287 with excellent enantioselectivities. This chemoselective reaction represents the first example of MAHTs as carboxylative nucleophiles. Nagasawa and co-workers were synthesized a guanidine-urea bifunctional catalyst that was expected to promote the reaction of 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds with peroxides to generate α-hydroxy-β-1,3-dicarbonyl compounds in the presence of base. Guanidine is known to interact with 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds through two parallel hydrogen bonds, while peroxides interact with urea groups. In this context, the enantioselective α-hydroxylation of β-ketoesters derived from 1-tetralone was explored [195]. 1-Tetralones are challenging substrates for oxidation reactions. Using (S,S)-guanidine-urea bifunctional catalyst 288a as the catalyst and cumene hydroperoxide 290 (CHP) as the oxidantin the presence of K2CO3 in toluene, the α-hydroxylation of β-keto tert-butyl ester 289 readily proceeded to give the hydroxylated product 291 in 90% yield with 93% ee (Scheme 113 ). The following transition-state model of the hydroxylation reaction catalyzed by 288 was proposed based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations (Fig. 8 ) [196]. In this model, four NH residues of the guanidinium and one urea group coordinate to two carbonyl groups in the keto ester substrate, effectively controlling the orientation of the keto ester enolate. The remaining two NH groups of the second urea group are suggested to activate cumene hydroperoxide through hydrogen bonding with the oxygen attached to the carbon in cumene. Through these multiple interactions, high enantioselectivity is suggested to arise. The presented catalytic asymmetric hydroxylation was applied to a more complex substrate 292, bearing a vinylogous β-keto moiety in the 2-pyridone structure. The reaction of 292 with CHP in the presence of guanidine-urea catalyst (S,S)-288b gave hydroxylated product 293 in 93% yield with 84% ee (Scheme 114 ) [197]. The enantiomeric excess of 293 was increased to 93% ee by a single recrystallization. The obtained product 293 is well known as a key synthetic intermediate in the synthesis of (20S)-camptothecin 294, which shows significant antitumor activity through inhibition of type I topoisomerase (Topo I) [198]. Sibi group have developed a catalytic process using thiourea/urea based catalyst 295a–f for the 6π-photocyclization of acrylanilides 296 that leads to 3,4-dihydroquinolin-2-one photoproducts 297 with low enantioselectivity (Scheme 115 ). Photophysical analyses have revealed excited state interaction between the catalyst and the substrate. Mechanistically, depending on the mode of excitation, 6π-photocyclization of acrylanilide 296 can occur either via a singlet excited state (e.g. direct excitation) or from a triplet excited state (e.g. triplet sensitization). Based on the photochemical reactivity paradigm and the ππ* excited state in acrylanilides [199], a zwitterionic intermediate is plausible from a singlet excited state and a diradicaloid intermediate is plausible from the triplet excited state. Under the experimental conditions, in the presence of catalyst 295, both a zwitterionic intermediate (ZW-1) and a triplet diradical intermediate (tDR-1) are feasible. Due to the parallel spin of electrons, tDR-1 (and tDR-1΄) has to inter system cross to form the product. The ZW-1 thus formed via a direct or sensitized irradiation will lead to photoproduct 297 via direct hydrogen migration or via an enol intermediate (Scheme 116 ). The authors believe that the partition of the reactive pathways either via ZW-1 intermediate (where a chiral form is preserved) and/or via the enol intermediate (where the chirality is destroyed) determines the enantiomeric excess in the photoproduct. It is clear from their photophysical studies that the catalyst and substrate interact in the excited state and this interaction is anchored by the hydrogen bonding. In spite of the interaction, the low enantioselectivity is likely a reflection of a combination of factors viz., (a) low stereodifferentiation in the presence of the catalyst with respect to the mode of cyclization; (b) formation of an enol intermediate that destroys the chirality; (c) relative reactivity of the zwitterion intermediate leading to enol formation that competes with direct hydrogen migration. The combination of these aspects are likely reflected in the observed low enantioselectivity in the product irrespective of the catalyst-substate interaction(s) in the excited state [200]. The first catalytic asymmetric Mukaiyama-Mannich reaction of ketimines and fluorinated silyl enol ethers is developed by Zhou and co-worker. Under the catalysis of hydroquinine derived bifunctional urea 298, cyclic N-sulfonyl ketimines 299 readily react with fluorinated enol silyl ethers 300 to afford benzosultam based C α-tetrasubstituted α-aminoacid derivatives 301 featuring a fluoroalkyl group in high to excellent yields and stereoselectivities (Scheme 117 ). The possible transition state was proposed and exemplified using difluorinated enol silylethers 300 (Fig. 9 ). The quinuclidine moiety of catalyst 298c activated difluoroenoxysilane 300 via n-σ* interaction between nitrogen and silicon atom, whilst the N-sulfonyl ketimines 299 was activated by urea moiety of 298c through H-bonding interaction. The attack of ketamine 299 by enol silyl ethers 300 was favored from the Re-face, as the steric repulsion between the aromatic ring of ketimine and enolate was avoided, affording S-enantiomer as major product [181]. Sakakura et al. in 2016, designed chiral phosphate-urea bifunctional catalysts 302a–d and 303a–b for the enantioselective bromocyclization of 2-geranylphenols 304. Catalyst 302a gave A-ring products 305 in good yield with good enantioselectivity. Subsequent treatment of 305 with TfOH gave trans-fused AB-ring products 306 as major diastereomers (Scheme 118 ). Hydrogen bonding interactions between the urea moiety of 302a and 2-hydroxyl group of the substrate strongly supported the enantioselective bromocyclization. The chiral triaryl phosphate moiety activates N-bromophthalimide (NBP) to generate a bromophosphonium ion. On the other hand, the urea moiety interacts with a hydroxyl group of the substrate through hydrogen bonding interactions. Enantioselectivity is effectively induced through two-point attractive interactions between the catalyst and substrate [201]. Shi and co-workers in 2016, reported the asymmetric fluorination of β-keto esters with N-fluorobisbenzenesulphonimide (NFSI) catalyzed by a PEG-bound urea-containing chiral quaternary ammonium salt 307 (Scheme 119 ). The corresponding products were obtained in good yields and enantioselectivities. The catalyst structure facilitated its recovery and multiple reuse without any loss of activity [202]. The marinopyrroles are a new class of natural products with highly interesting biomedical and structural features. Gulder and co-workers provide a concise, nitrogen-protective-group-free synthesis of marinopyrrole 309, constituting the as yet most efficient route. The presented studies elaborate a straight forward and mild chlorination protocol. Moreover, the first study towards the atropselective synthesis of marinopyrrole (M)-310 with 2–11% ee, using chiral, C2-symmetric bisthiourea catalysts 308a–d, is presented (Scheme 120 ) [203]. 9 Urea derivatives immobilization on nano solid acids as nano-organo-acid-catalysts Two novel, mild, green and efficient nano structure organo solid acids, carbamoyl sulfamic acid 311, 2-carbamoylhydrazine-1-sulfonic acid 312, with urea as a biological moiety were designed and synthesized by Zolfigol and co-workers (Scheme 121 ). They investigated catalytic property of these organo solid acids for the synthesis of 4,4′-(arylmethylene)bis(1H-pyrazol-5-ol) 314, coumarin-3-carboxylic acid 317 and cinnamic acid derivatives 318 via the condensation reaction between several aromatic aldehydes and: 1-phenyl-3-methylpyrazol-5-one 313 [synthesis of 4,4′-(arylmethylene)bis(1H-pyrazol-5-ols) 314]; the Knoevenagel condensation of Meldrum’s acid 315 with salicylaldehyde derivatives 316 (synthesis of coumarin-3-carboxylic acids 317) and; the condensation of Meldrum’s acid 315 with aromatic aldehydes (synthesis of cinnamic acids 318) under mild, green and solvent-free conditions (Scheme 122 ). Further studies showed that the nano structure organocatalyst acidity plays a major role in the dual-catalyzed reactions. Significant advantages of these reactions are that they are relatively environmentally benign, biological-based, low cost, have a cleaner reaction profile, high yields, short reaction time, simple product isolation, reusable catalysts and close agreement with green chemistry guidelines. Finally, on the basis of their observations and the above mentioned advantages, herein, the authors think that both of the described biological-based acids and/or catalysts have potential for industrial production [204]. 10 Urea polymer derivatives as organocatalysts Urea-functionalized mesoporous polymers (urea-MPs) were synthesized through the surfactant-directed urea-phenol-formaldehyde oligomers self-assembly approach. The urea-MPs were prepared by the surfactant-directed evaporation induced self-assembly (EISA) approach using urea- resin oligomers (urea-ROs) precursor and block copolymer F127 (Scheme 123 ). In a typical synthetic procedure, F127 was added into 25 ml ethanol solution composing of urea-RO and stirred for 2 h to form a clear solution. The mixture was transferred into dishes and exposed in air at 30 °C for 8 h to evaporate ethanol and further thermo-polymerized at 120 °C for 24 h. The as-made materials were calcined in a tubular furnace at 350 °C for 4 h in argon atmosphere to remove F127 template. The final products were denoted as urea-MPs-319a, urea-MPs-319b and urea-MPs-319c, which involved with three corresponding urea-RO precursor as functional building blocks. The nitrogencontent were determined by elemental analysis. The as-prepared urea-MPs material exhibited superior catalytic activity than parent urea in water-medium Knoevenagel condensation reactions between benzaldehyde and various substances could be used repetitively for seven times (Scheme 124 ). The excellent activity could be attributed to the synergic effect derived from the secondary amine with the surface phenolic groups in the mesoporous support, which generated the acid-base cooperative catalytic behavior. Meanwhile, the urea functional groups embedded in the mesoporous wall could inhibit the leaching of active species and thus resulted in the relatively good durability [205]. In order to overcome existing solid catalysts' disadvantages of low stability and activity, urea-derived graphitic carbon nitrides 320 (u-g-C3N4) with higher stabilities and more active centers were prepared under different temperatures (550–450 °C) by Cheng group. g-C3N4 derived from urea promises to be a good choice due to the simple synthetic steps without template addition (Scheme 125 ). With a decrease in preparation temperature from 550 °C to 480 °C, a u-g-C3N4 of lower crystallinity with a smaller polymerization degree was obtained and found to have a higher catalytic activity for CO2 conversion into propylene carbonate (Scheme 126 ). The higher activity of the u-g-C3N4 caused by decreasing the temperature might be ascribed to the lower crystallinity and polymerization degree, which led to more edge defects, wherein the incompletely-coordinated nitrogen atoms served as the main active sites in the cycloaddition reaction. Among all the prepared catalysts, one which is prepared at 480 °C (u-g-C3N4-480) showed the highest catalytic activity for CO2 conversion and exhibited great suitability for other epoxide substrates [206]. 11 Urea derivatives supported on magnetic nanoparticles as organo-magnetic-nanoparticle catalysts In all catalysts available in Sections 11–13, urea derivatives are supported on various substrates so that they act as catalyst or linker and mechanism of some reactions is mentioned in some cases. In 2011, Connon group synthesized the immobilized bifunctional urea 324 as follow: addition of the thiol 322 to the known quinine-derived urea 321 in the presence of AIBN afforded the sulfide 323, [207] which could be isolated and then loaded on to magnetite nanoparticles as before (using 4-iodoanisole as an internal standard to facilitate quantitative 1H NMR spectroscopic analysis) with 100% efficiency to afford catalyst 324 with a catalyst loading of 0.1 mmol g−1 (Scheme 127 ) [208]. This catalyst (324) was evaluated as a promoter of the asymmetric addition of dimethyl malonate 325 to (E)-β-nitrostyrene allowed the formation of 326 in a comparable 71% ee (Scheme 128 ). In another work, urea-functionalized silica-based magnetite hybrid core-shell nanoparticles 327 were prepared through a facile and simple procedure starting from commercially available raw materials by Maleki group (Scheme 129 ). It was found that the magnetic nanocatalyst can be utilized as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the one-pot three-component condensation reaction of benzyl 328 or benzoin 329 with various substituted aldehydes and ammonium acetate in refluxing ethanol in short reaction times and excellent yields under mild reaction conditions.
