The catalyst was recycled at least five times without significant decrease in the catalytic activity. This procedure includes further important aspects like the easy workup procedure, reusability of the catalyst, high atom economy, excellent yields, and environmentally benign reaction conditions [209]. Urea-based ionic liquid stabilized on silica-coated Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles, {Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-Urea-SO3H/HCl} 336, as an unexceptionable and smooth releasing urea fertilizer in alkali soils was synthesized and fully characterized by Zolfigol group. In order to synthesize this catalyst, a mixture including Fe3O4, water, ethanol, ammonia and tetraethylorthosilicate 331 (TEOS) was refluxed to afford silica-coated Fe3O4 332 (Fe3O4@SiO2). Subsequently, Fe3O4@SiO2 and (3-chloropropyl)triethoxysilane 333 in dry toluene were refluxed under nitrogen for 12 h and Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3Cl 334 was obtained. Then urea in dry toluene was added to the Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3Cl 334 and Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-Urea 335 was produced finally, chlorosulfonic acid was added dropwise to Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-Urea 335 in dry dichloromethane and the mixture was stirred for 6 h and {Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-Urea-SO3H/HCl} 336 was obtained. The synthesis is shown in Scheme 131 . The nanostructure catalyst as a novel, green and efficient catalyst was applied for the synthesis of bis(indolyl)methane derivatives 337 via the condensation reaction between 2-methylindole and aldehydes at room temperature under solvent-free conditions. Also, pyrano[2,3-d]pyrimidinone derivatives 339 were prepared in the presence of the nanomagnetic urea-based catalyst 336 by the one-pot three-component condensation reaction of 1,3-dimethylbarbituric acid 338, aldehydes and malononitrile under solvent-free conditions at 60 °C (Scheme 132 ). Noteworthy advantages are relatively high yield, short reaction time, simplicity of product isolation, clean reaction profile, environmental benignity, recyclability and reusability of the magnetic nano particles@ionic liquids (MNPs@ILs) catalyst which are in close agreement with green chemistry disciplines. Since urea and its salts have been used as most important nitrogen-based fertilizers in the world of agriculture, any new simple urea derivatives may have potential for large-scale applications. On the other hand, one of the main limitations of urea fertilizer is the high releasing rate of ammonia in soil, whereas the authors think that their described MNPs@ILs is an unexceptionable alternative and smooth releasing urea fertilizer for applying in alkali soils. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of the synthesis of urea-based IL stabilized on silica-coated Fe3O4 MNPs. As revealed in Scheme 133 , the authors suggest a probable mechanism for the reaction. Initially, the MNP catalyst activates the carbonyl group of the aromatic aldehyde to provide intermediate 340, which is followed by indole attacking 340 to afford 342 and loss of one molecule of water from 342 gives 343. Afterwards a second molecule of indole is added to indole which in the following step affords the product 337 and MNP catalyst, which can catalyze the reaction in a catalytic process. Synthesis of pyrano[2,3-d]pyrimidinone derivatives is done with a similar mechanism which has be mentioned in the reference [210]. A reusable and mild semicarbazide-based ionic liquid stabilized on silica-coated Fe3O4 MNPs, namely {Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-NHNHCO-NH-SO3H/HCl} 345, was designed, synthesized and fully characterized by Zolfigol and co-workers. Application of this catalyst was studied for the synthesis of 3,3′-(arylmethylene)bis (4-hydroxycoumarin) 347 and 1-carbamato-alkyl-2-naphthol 350 derivatives via the condensation reaction between 4-hydroxycoumarin 346 and aromatic aldehydes at 80 °C under solvent-free conditions (synthesis of 3,3′-(arylmethylene)bis(4-hydroxycoumarin) derivatives 347) and one-pot three-component condensation reaction of aromatic aldehydes with benzyl carbamate 348 and β-naphthol 349 at 70 °C (synthesis of 1-carbamato-alkyl-2-naphthol derivatives 350) under efficient, green, mild and solvent-free conditions (Scheme 134 ) [211]. In this investigation, Zolfigol group has explored the catalytic applicability of the organocatalysts 351, 352 and recent biological-based nano catalysts 353, 354 with urea moiety in the synthesis of arylbispyranylmethane derivatives (Scheme 135 ). The benefits of these procedures are the reducing of the reaction times, improving of the yields, benign and eco-friendly reaction conditions, step and atom viability, easy work-up and purification of the desired products. Since that the recyclability and reusability is a major factor for influencing the suitability of any catalyst, we observed that the nano magnetic catalysts 336, 345 are more recyclable than the described organocatalysts 351, 352. Results are summarized in Table 1 [212]. Urea-functionalized silica-coated magnetic core-shell Fe3-x TixO4 nanoparticles 355 (Fe3-x TixO4@SiO2@urea) were prepared and fully characterized by Azarifar and co-workers. These magnetic nanoparticles have been explored as highly efficient and recoverable heterogeneous nanocatalyst for one-pot three-component reactions under mild conditions for the synthesis of diverse range of 5-oxodihydropyrano[3,2-c]chromenes 357 known as coumarins via the condensation reaction between aromatic aldehyde, malononitrile and 4-hydroxycoumarin and 1H-pyrazolo[1,2-b] phthalazine-5,10-diones 358 in high yields via the condensation reaction between aromatic aldehyde, malononitrile and phthalhydrazide 356 (Scheme 136 ) [213]. Zolfigol et al. in the course of using urea in the Biginelli reaction [214–221], have also reported a facile synthetic method for the synthesis of Fe3O4@SiO2@urea and Fe3O4@SiO2@urethane catalysts 359a–d (Fig. 10 ). The silica-coated magnetic nanoparticles were simply functionalized via addition of 3-(triethoxysilyl)propylisocyanate (TESPIC), amine or amino alcohol. These easily recyclable catalysts were used efficiently for one-pot multicomponent synthesis of α-aminonitriles 360 in Strecker reaction using numerous aldehydes or ketones, TMSCN and amines under solvent-free conditions at 50 °C (Scheme 137 ). Due to the integrative combination of various advantages such as facile synthesis, ease of recovery and solvent-free reaction conditions, the protocol presented can be considered as an environmentally benign approach for synthesizing α-aminonitriles 360 via the Strecker reaction [222]. Gholinejad and co-workers prepared and characterized a magnetic nanoparticle-supported oxime palladacycle catalyst 361. Using this catalyst, structurally different aryl iodides and bromides were reacted effectively with arylboronic acids 362 in aqueous media at room temperature (Scheme 138 ). The catalyst was shown to be highly active under phosphine-free and low Pd loading (0.3 mol%) conditions. The catalyst could be easily separated from the reaction mixture using an external magnet and reused for six consecutive runs without significant loss of activity [223]. In 2016, magnetically recoverable hydroxyapatite-modified γ-Fe2O3 magnetic nanoparticles grafted with guanidinium chloride 363 (γ-Fe2O3@HAP-GndCl nanoparticles) as nanocatalyst were successfully prepared and fully characterized by Azarifar group. The newly synthesized γ-Fe2O3@HAP-GndCl MNPs 363 were explored as excellent heterogeneous nanocatalyst to effect the one-pot three-component condensation reactions of various aromatic aldehydes, malononitrile and 3-cyano-6-hydroxy-4-methylpyridin-2(1H)-one 364 for the synthesis of 4H-pyrano[2,3-b]pyridine-3,6-dicarbonitrile derivatives 365 under green solvent-free condition with excellent yields (Scheme 139 ) [224]. Azarifar and co-workers have successfully prepared the thiourea dioxide-functionalized hydroxyapatite-encapsulated hybrid coreshell magnetic nanoparticles (γ-Fe2O3@HAp-TUD MNPs) 366 and fully characterized by analytical techniques (Fig. 11 ). This newly prepared acidic nanocatalyst has been explored as heterogeneous magnetic nanocatalyst for the synthesis of 4H-pyrano[2,3-b]pyridine-3,6-dicarbonitrile derivatives 365. The advantages of the present method are high yields of the products, low reaction times, simple work-up procedure and efficient recyclability and reusability of the catalyst. Thus, the present method offers improvements on the synthesis of the titled products over other existing methods [225]. In another study, the catalytic performance of magnetically recoverable solid acid namely Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-Urea-SO3H/HCl 336 was inspected in the synthesis of 2′-aminobenzothiazolomethylnaphthol derivatives 369 by Zolfigol group (Scheme 140 ). In a suggested mechanism for the synthesis of 1-(benzo[d]thiazol-2 ylamino)(phenyl)methyl)naphthalen-2-ol 369, as depicted in Scheme 141 , presumably the mechanistic process initiate by the in-situ generation of compound 367 as o-Quinone Methide (o-QM) intermediate. Afterward, a Michael addition of 2-aminobenzthiazole to intermediate 367, gives intermediate 368. Finally, proton transfer offered desired molecules 369 (Scheme 141) [226]. 12 Urea derivatives supported on silica as organocatalysts Zhao Group have developed a highly efficient and practical method for the synthesis of unsymmetrical diaryl sulfides through Chan-Lam coupling reaction of arylboronic acids 371 with thiols by using an MCM-41-immobilized 1,10-phenanthrolinecopper(II) complex [MCM-41-1,10-Phen-CuSO4] 370 as catalyst and n-Bu4NOH (40% aq) as base in EtOH at room temperature under O2 atmosphere in good to excellent yields under mild and green conditions. The new heterogeneous copper complex can easily be prepared by a simple procedure from commercially readily available and inexpensive reagents, and recovered by a simple filtration of the reaction solution and recycled for at least eight times without significant loss of catalytic activity (Scheme 142 ) [227]. Lin and co-workers reported a cooperative catalytic system comprising a series of bifunctionalized mesoporous silica nanosphere (MSN) materials with various relative concentrations of a general acid, the ureidopropyl (UDP) group, and a general base, the 3-[2-(2-aminoethylamino)ethylamino]-propyl (AEP) group (Fig. 12 ). The AEP/UDP–MSN materials 372 were employed as catalysts for different reactions involving carbonyl activation such as aldol, Henry, and cyanosilylation reactions (Scheme 143 ). In these reactions, the secondary amines of the AEP group were shown to be responsible for the enamine formation with acetone (aldol reaction), the deprotonation of CH3NO2 (Henry reaction), and the generation of a potential nucleophile from (CH3)3SiCN through hypervalent silicate formation (cyanosilylation). Benzaldehyde was activated by UDP group via H-bonding with urea part in this structure (Scheme 144 ) [228]. 13 Sugar-derived bifunctional chiral ureas as organocatalyst Saccharides, as naturally occurring compounds with defined stereogenic centre, are useful building blocks for many interesting structures [229–231]. Carbohydrates, which are inexpensive and readily available natural materials, have been also employed as chiral backbones of organocatalysts. Examples of application of urea saccharide organocatalyst in asymmetric synthesis can be found in the literatures [232,233]. Another significant feature of saccharides is their hydrophilicity which enables to perform enantioselective syntheses under aqueous media. Porwanski and co-workers have developed a simple and efficient methodology for the synthesis of sugar-derived bifunctional chiral urea organocatalysts 373a–f. The effectiveness of this class of organocatalysts was demonstrated in the aza-Henry reaction. The aza-Henry reaction of imines with nitromethane was promoted by sugar derived bifunctional organocatalysts to give optically active ß-nitroamines. The products were obtained in good yields (35–98%) and ee up to 99% (Scheme 145 ). Proposed transition state for catalyst 373e of this asymmetric aza-Henry reaction is illustrated in Fig. 13 . The urea moiety forms a hydrogen-bond with the nitromethane and tertiary nitrogen detaches proton from the methyl group. These effects of the catalyst facilitate the controlled attack of nitromethane for imine carbonyl atom (Fig. 13) [234]. In 2014, chiral ureas containing glycosyl and diphenylphosphinyl scaffolds derivatives were prepared using simple procedure by Porwanski. Organocatalysts 374k and 374 l were efficiently used for the asymmetric Morita-Baylis-Hillman reaction of an acrylate with an aldehyde. Yields of this reaction were moderate with an enantiomeric excess of up to 80% (Scheme 146 ) [235]. 14 Cucurbiturils and substituted glycolurils as multi rule urea-based organocatalysts Cucurbiturils (CBn) are a relatively young class of macrocyclic receptor molecules composed of methylene-bridged glycoluril monomers having highly symmetrical hydrophobic cavities accessible through two identical, highly polarizable carbonyl laced portals Fig. 14 [236–241]. Different homologues of cucurbit[n]urils (commonly abbreviated as CBn or in some cases CB[n], Q[n], Qn, or Cucn; n = 5–10 and 14, represents the number of glycoluril units in the macrocycle) with various cavity and portal dimensions are known [237–240]. Among the set of CBs, the complexation behavior of cucurbit[7]uril (CB7) has been extensively studied due to its appropriate cavity size and portal diameter comparable to the dimension (width) of most small size organic guests and also due to its substantial solubility in water as compared to the other homologues like CB5, CB6, CB8, and CB10 [237,240]. The water solubility of the CBn can be enhanced in the presence of salts, at low pH, or in the presence of charged guests [237,240]. All CB homologues, except CB5, can form much stronger host/guest complexes than cyclodextrins (CDs), and their binding constants range typically from 104 to 1015 M−1 [240,242]. Very recently, this class of macrocycles has been shown to exhibit low in vitro as well as in vivo toxicity, thereby facilitating biologically relevant applications of these macrocycles. Nau groups carried out a phase-selective photolysis of bicyclic azoalkanes (2,3-diazabicyclo[2.2.1]hept-2-ene 375 and 2,3-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octa-2-ene 378 promoted by transition metal ions coordinated to the CB7 rim (Scheme 147 ). The reaction was selected to afford a photoproduct with a reduced affinity to the host and with a higher solubility in an organic phase than in water. In detail, irradiation of 375 and 378 in their near-UV n, π*absorption band in water is known to cause nitrogen extrusion under formation of bicyclo[2.1.0]pentane (housane) 376 as exclusive photoproduct of 375 and of a 70: 30 mixture of 1,5-hexadien 379 and bicyclo[2.2.0]hexane 380; the conversion can be conveniently monitored by gas chromatography. In the presence of CB7 and of specific transition metal ions (Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Ag+, also Tl+), the photolysis of DBO afforded a 5-fold to 10-fold excess of the diene product. The chemoselectivity was postulated to occur from the triplet-excited state, populated by heavy-atom-induced intersystem crossing. With the smaller azoalkane 375, surprisingly, cyclopentene 377 was formed as a new photoproduct (41%), but only in the presence of both, CB7 and Ag+. Because the formation of a ternary complex between CB7, Ag+, and 378 could be crystallographically established, it is likely that a new mechanism, photoinduced electron-transfer, leads to cyclopentene. Such redox-active ternary complexes can be considered as metalloenzyme models [243]. Zolfigol et al. prepared a crabby biological-based glycoluril tetrakis(methylene) tetrakis(phosphonic acid) (GTMTPA) 381 for the first time. Two convenient methods for the synthesis of novel biological henna-based 3-methyl-1,4-diphenyl-1,4- dihydrobenzo[6,7]chromeno[2,3-c]pyrazole-5,10-diones 382 were also reported in the presence of described nano glycoluril tetrakis(methylene) tetrakis (phosphonic acid) (GTMTPA) as an efficient and recyclable catalyst under neat conditions (Scheme 148 ). The major advantages of the presented method are high yields, short reaction times, and the reusability of the catalyst [244]. As shown, the aldehyde is initially activated by GTMTPA towards the nucleophilic attack of 2-hydroxynaphthalene-1,4-dione affording, after dehydration, the 3-methylenenaphthalene intermediate C. Then, 5-methyl-2-phenylpyrazolidin-3-one (obtained from ethyl acetoacetate and phenyl hydrazine) reacts via conjugate addition with C to afford adduct D, which suffers an intramolecular cyclization/dehydration process assisted by 381 to give intermediate E. Finally deprotonation of E yields the desired product (Scheme 149 ). 15 Conclusions In summary, urea and its derivatives are biological materials that are widely recognized as highly useful templates upon which powerful organocatalytic systems, both mono- and bifunctional, can be constructed. It is known that urea derivatives have been used as efficient Lewis-acidic catalysts for organic transformations due to effective H-bondings that are formed with the amide hydrogens. Urea organocatalysis derivatives have been also used as basic catalyst, coupling with metals as catalyst, chiral acidic catalysts, urea anions catalysts, coupling with ionic liquids, urea polymer catalysts and immobilization on solid acid and other supports, too. Recently urea derivatives are immobilized on magnetic nanoparticles as retrievable and reusable catalysts. Homogeneous and heterogeneous urea derivatives widely applied as catalysts for various reactions such as: Claisen rearrangements, Diels-Alder reactions, Baylis-Hillman reaction, Friedel-Crafts type reactions, ring-opening reactions, Strecker reactions and etc. In the future, there are intriguing opportunities for the development of novel biological urea based catalytic systems, which could enable multistep transformations in one-pot. This review article will be present an excellent puzzle that each of its pieces lead to the rational design, synthesis and applications of novel and tasked-specific catalytic systems alike of biological enzymes with peptide linkages. Finally, knowledge-based development of biomimetic reactions needs biological like catalytic systems such as urea-based catalysts. We are sure that these novel organocatalytic systems would play a significant, vital and important role in the synthesis and production of wide variety of new valuable compounds in the future technologies. Sel . 3 2018 3042 3047 10.1002/slct.201702544 Bahareh Atashkar was born in 1980 in Bukan (West Azarbayjan) and obtained her B.Sc. from Kurdistan University, her M.Sc. from University of Kurdistan with Dr. Farogh Nasiri as supervisor, and her Ph.D in 2013, from Kurdistan University with Dr. Amin Rostami. Curently, she is a Post Doctoral Research fellow with Prof. Mohammad Ali Zolfigol in Bu-Ali Sina University. Atashkar’s research involves the study and development of new synthetic methods through the synthesis and application of new magnetic nanoparticles-supported reagents. Mohammad Ali Zolfigol was born in 1966 in Salehabad (Ashtian-AraK) and obtained his B.Sc. from Arak University, his M.Sc. from Isfahan University of Technology with Prof. Shadpour Mallakpour as supervisor, and his Ph.D from Shiraz University with Prof. Nasser Iranpoor and Professor Habib Frouzabadi as supervisor and advisor respectively. He has been a faculty member of Bu-Ali Sina University since 1997 and was promoted to Professor in 2005. The Ministry of Science, Research and Technology of Iran selected him as a distinguished researcher in 2001 and distinguished lecturer in 2015. He won 21st International Khwarizmi Festival and COMSTEC awards in 2008 and also Allameh Tabataba'i's award of Iran National Elites Fundation in 2015. Zolfigol became General Secretary of Chemical Society of Iran in 2007 till now. He has been the president of Bu-Ali Sina University since 2008 till 2013. Zolfigol’s research involves the exploration and development of new synthetic methods through the synthesis and application of novel and task specific reagents, catalysts, ionic liquids and silica-based resins in chemical processes. Professor Shadpour Mallakpour, organic polymer chemist, graduated from chemistry department, University of Florida (UF), Gainesville, Florida, U.S.A. in 1984. He spent two years as post-doc at UF. He joint to the department of chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology (IUT), Iran, since 1986. He held several positions such as chairman of department of chemistry and deputy of research, department of chemistry at IUT. From 1994–1995 he worked as visiting professor, University of Mainz, Germany and from 2003 to 2004 as visiting professor, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, USA. Now he has published more than 750 journal papers and more than 430 conference papers and got more than 32 items of awards. The most important award to him was given for the selection of first laureate on fundamental research, at 21st Khwarizmi International award in 2008. He is listed as the Top 1% Scientists in Chemistry in ISI Essential Science Indicators Since 2003. He was selected as academic guest of the 59th Meeting of Nobel Prize Winners in Chemistry, 2009, at Lindau, Germany. He presented many lectures as invited or keynote speaker in different national and international conferences or universities. He was member of organizing and scientific committees for many national and international conferences. He was also the chairperson of many national and international meetings. In recent years he focused on the preparation and characterization of polymers containing chiral amino acid moieties under green conditions using ionic liquids and microwave irradiation as new technology and bringing these aspects towards nanotechnology for the preparation of novel chiral bionanocomposite polymers as well as polymer nanocomposities for hazardous materials removal technologies.

coredata.dc:description: The present critical review outlines the close relationship and mutual interplay between molecular recognition, active site considerations in enzyme catalysis involving organocatalysis via hydrogen bonding. These interconnections are generally not made although; as we demonstrated they are quite apparent as exemplified with pertinent examples in the field of urea organocatalysis. Urea organocatalysis derivatives have been used as efficient Lewis-acidic catalysts due to effective H-bonding, basic catalyst, coupling with metals as catalyst, chiral acid catalysts, urea anions catalysts, coupling with ionic liquids, urea polymer catalysts and immobilization on solid acid and magnetic nanoparticle supports. Consecutively, the discovery and mechanistic elucidation of such reactions are likely to improve the understanding of enzyme active sites.
coredata.dc:title: Applications of biological urea-based catalysts in chemical processes
